Classes & Value Types

Emojicode features three kind of types that feature characteristics of object-orientation: Classes, Value Types and Enumerations. This chapter is soley dedicated to classes and value types. A separate chapter is devoted to enumerations, which have a lot in common with value types.

Classes versus Value Types

There are two significant differences between classes and value types:

  • Instances of classes are always allocated on the heap and are passed by reference. Instances of value types are, as their name suggests, passed by value.

  • Classes feature inheritance while value types donâ€™t.

This makes value types suitable when only the actual data represented matters and not the identity of the object. In other words, you should use value types when you only care about the values they carry and not about whether you have a particular instance of the value type.

Dates or mathematical vectors are good examples of types that should be value types, whereas a type representing a customer should be a class, as it does matter with which customer youâ€™re dealing and not just the data it holds. Think of it like this: There may be many customers named â€œJohn Smithâ€ but the customers are still different people and therefore are represented by different objects.

Defining a Class

Let us define a class representing a customer:

ğŸ‡ ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰

As mentioned previously, classes feature inheritance. We can therefore also declare a subclass of our ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ class:

ğŸ‡ ğŸ‘©â€ğŸš€ ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰

Some of our customers are astronauts, so we created the subclass ğŸ‘©â€ğŸš€. To make a class a subclass, denote its superclass behind the new classes name. If you donâ€™t provide a superclass, the class doesnâ€™t have one.

Defining a Value Type

Naturally, we also need to maintain our customers credit card information to be able to bill them. Credit card information is a great example of a value type so letâ€™s define one:

ğŸ•Š ğŸ’³ ğŸ‡

The definition of a value type is quite similar to the definition of a class. We just used ğŸ•Š instead of ğŸ‡. Furthermore, value types cannot have a supertype.

Instance Variables

We have declared various types now, but so far these are pretty useless as they do not store any information at all.

Let us change this by adding instance variables. The normal syntax for declaring variables is used in value types and classes too:

ğŸ•Š ğŸ’³ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ–ğŸ†• number ğŸ”¡
  ğŸ–ğŸ†• expiration_date ğŸ”¡

ğŸ‰

We have added some variables to store the credit card information. (We do not maintain that this is a particularly good way of structuring credit card information but this is just an example. ğŸ™ƒ)

ğŸ‰

We have also added some information to the normal customer ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ and the astronaut customer ğŸ‘©â€ğŸš€.

Instance variables are private to the instance and cannot be accessed from outside but only in initializers and methods. If you want to access instance variables from outside you have to write getters and setters. Instance variables are also kept private from subclasses.

Syntax

We have summarized the syntax here as it is a great deal of definitions and we didnâ€™t want to clutter the previous sections.

Initializers

Initializers are responsible to prepare an instance for use and when you create a new instance of the type.

In an initializer all instance variables must be initialized. Remember that variables of an optional type are automatically initialized to no value, which is also true for instance variables.

Let us define an initializer:

ğŸ•Š ğŸ’³ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ–ğŸ†• number ğŸ”¡
  ğŸ–ğŸ†• expiration_date ğŸ”¡
  ğŸ–ğŸ†• security_code ğŸ”¡

  ğŸ†• a_number ğŸ”¡ an_expiration_date ğŸ”¡ a_security_code ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
    a_number â¡ï¸ğŸ–number
    an_expiration_date â¡ï¸ğŸ–expiration_date
    a_security_code â¡ï¸ğŸ–security_code
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰

Now that was some tedious work, assigning all that instance variables. Because it is common to initialize instance variables from parameters, Emojicode provides a shortcut: ğŸ¼.

ğŸ¼ is placed in front of the variable name of an parameters. Its value is then copied into the instance variable with the same name:

ğŸ†• ğŸ¼ number ğŸ”¡ ğŸ¼ expiration_date ğŸ”¡ ğŸ¼ security_code ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡ğŸ‰

This is much better. Let us add an initializers to ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ as well.

ğŸ‡ ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ–ğŸ†• firstname ğŸ”¡

ğŸ‰

Before implementing an initializer for ğŸ‘©â€ğŸš€ we must review one additional rule: If youâ€™re writing an initializer for class that has a superclass you must call an initializer of the superclass. â¤´ï¸ is used for that:

Instantiation

We have defined a value type and two classes, defined how to inititalize them, but we have yet to actually instantiate (get an instance) of them. Instatiation is performed with ğŸ†•.

Its syntax is:

instantiation âŸ¶ ğŸ†• type-expr initializer [arguments] mood

Let us instantiate a credit card information ğŸ’³:

ğŸ†•ğŸ’³ğŸ†• ğŸ”¤48829284848291ğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤12/22ğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤513ğŸ”¤â—ï¸ â¡ï¸ credit_card

The following expressions are argumetns to the initializer. â—ï¸ denotes the end of the arguments.

Methods

Methods are functionality bound to a specific type: a class or value type.

The syntax to define a method is:

method âŸ¶ identification [generic-parameters] [parameters] [return-type] body
identification âŸ¶ mood emoji-id | binary-operator
mood âŸ¶ â—ï¸ | â“
parameters âŸ¶ parameter | parameter parameters
parameter âŸ¶ variable type
return-type âŸ¶ â¡ï¸ type

Let us define a method for ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ to print an invoice:

  ğŸ˜€ ğŸª ğŸ”¤Your credit card will be charged. ğŸ”¤ ğŸªâ—ï¸

Returning values

Methods can, of course, also return a value. Unless you declare a return type, the method is assumed to not return a value.

Let us add a method to ğŸ’³ that returns a value:

â—ï¸ ğŸ”– â¡ï¸  ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
  â†©ï¸ number
ğŸ‰

This method simply returns the credit card number. It uses the return statement â†©ï¸ to return the value from the method.

return âŸ¶ â†©ï¸ expression

Method Moods

In Emojicode every method has a mood. The methods we have previously defined, are of imperative mood as we used â—ï¸. The other mood is interrogative. Interrogative methods are defined with â“ instead.

The mood is like part of the name of the method. You can have an interrogative and imperative method with the same basic name.

Let us define an interrogative method for the ğŸ‘©â€ğŸš€ class:

â“ ğŸš€ â¡ï¸ ğŸ‘Œ ğŸ‡
  â†©ï¸ days_in_space â–¶ï¸ 0
ğŸ‰

This method returns true if the astronaut ever boarded a rocket. We can define an imperative method with the same name that allows us to change the number of days the astronaut spent in space:

â—ï¸ ğŸš€ days ğŸ”¢ ğŸ‡
  days â¡ï¸ ğŸ–days_in_space
ğŸ‰

Calling Methods

We have defined two methods, but we have yet to fully understand how to call a method.

Weâ€™ll have a look at some examples first:

ğŸ’¸ astronaut_picard 109.12â—ï¸
ğŸ’¸ customer_mouse 59.00â—ï¸
ğŸš€ astronaut_picardâ“ ğŸ’­ Was he ever in space?
ğŸš€ astronaut_picard 6390â—ï¸ ğŸ’­ Change the number of days to 6390

As you can see above, the syntax to call a method is special:

method-call âŸ¶ emoji-id callee [generic-arguments] [arguments] mood
callee âŸ¶ expression
arguments âŸ¶ expression [arguments]

If an emoji occurs that is not reserved for a built-in statement or expression (e.g. â†©ï¸ or ğŸš¨), it is considered a method call. The compiler then expects an expression, evaluating to a value that has method with the provided name. Then arguments are expected until either â—ï¸ or â“ occurs.

A method call expression evaluates to the value the method return. If the method does not declare a return type, the call expression returns a value of type no return, which is neither compatible to any type nor does it offer any functionality.

This Context

You often will want to get the instance on which the method was called, this is the object or the value. This is what ğŸ• is for.

ğŸ• returns the current value, whose method or initializer is being called.

For example, we could add a method to the ğŸ‘©â€ğŸš€ class that bills an astronaut if has traveled to space:

â—ï¸ ğŸ›¸ ğŸ‡
  ğŸŠ ğŸš€ ğŸ•â“ ğŸ‡
    ğŸ’¸ğŸ• 100â—ï¸
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰

Note that in an initializer, you canâ€™t use ğŸ• before the object is fully initialized, that is before all instance variables were set and the superinitializer was called. If this was allowed, you could call methods on the instance which might access instance variable that had not been initialized yet.

Type Methods

Itâ€™s possible to define type methods which are called on the type rather than on an instance of the type.

Type methods are defined like normal methods but with the ğŸ‡ attribute. As for example:

ğŸ‡ ğŸ• ğŸ‡
  ğŸŒ® Return available pizza dishes. ğŸŒ®
  ğŸ‡â—ï¸ ğŸ“œ â¡ï¸ ğŸ¨ğŸšğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
    â†©ï¸ ğŸ¨ ğŸ”¤MargheritağŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤TonnoğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤Quattro FormaggiğŸ”¤ ğŸ†
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰

Since type methods donâ€™t execute in an object context the use of ğŸ• is illegal. Type methods are also inherited by subclasses.

We can call our type method like this:

ğŸ“œğŸ‡ğŸ•â—ï¸

This calls the type method ğŸ“œ on the class ğŸ•, which we just defined above. To learn more about this syntax please see Types As Values.

Access Levels

Access Levels describe from which context a method or initializer can be called. There are three access levels:

access-level âŸ¶ ğŸ”“ | ğŸ”’ | ğŸ”
  • ğŸ”“: The method or initializer can be accessed from everywhere.
  • ğŸ”’: The method or initializer may only be accessed within the type and package it was defined.
  • ğŸ”: The method or initializer may only be accessed within the type it was defined or within a class that inherits from that class that defined this method.

Deprecation

From time to time methods or initializers need to be deprecated. Emojicode allows you to mark a method or initializer as deprecated with the âš ï¸ attribute.

The compiler will emit a warning wherever a deprecated method or initializer is used.
